;

;

;6 月份中国工厂活动延续跌势，增加证明世界第二大经济体在第二季度因需求减弱而失去动力。

;

;6 月份官方制造业采购经理人指数 (PMI) 从 5 月份的 48.8 升至 49，但仍保持在低于月度增长与收缩的 50 分界线。

;

;野村分析师表示，官方制造业 PMI 的小幅反弹集中在生产方面，新订单分类指数也从 48.3 微升至 48.6

;

;但新出口订单分类指数跌至五个月低点 46.4，直接纳入整体制造业 PMI 计算的五个分类指数中的三个在 6 月份小幅下降。

;

;与此同时，财新/标普全球制造业 PMI 从 5 月份的 50.9 回落至 6 月份的 50.5，表明经济活动略有扩张。

;

;凯投宏观 (Capital Economics) 中国经济学家朱利安·埃文斯-普里查德 (Julian Evans-Pritchard) 和谢娜·岳 (Sheana Yue) 表示：“财新指数显示，有利于小型企业和靠近海岸的企业的有利因素正在减弱。”

;

;取官方和财新的平均值调查显示，产出部分下降，似乎反映出外国需求下行压力加大。

;

;虽然新订单部分基本保持不变，但出口订单部分进一步下降至五个月低点，表明出口再次下降。

;

;“总的来说，两者的平均值与上个月工厂活动的轻微恶化相符，”Evans-Pritchard 和 Yue 补充道。

;

;

;

;由于对现场服务的需求减弱，6 月份中国服务业的活动也放缓。

;

;衡量服务业和建筑业商业信心的官方非制造业 PMI部门，从 5 月的 54.5 降至 6 月的 53.2。

;

;在非制造业指标中，服务业分类指数从 5 月的 53.8 降至 6 月的 52.8，而建筑业分类指数则跌至六个月低点野村证券 (Nomura) 分析师指出，在为期三天的端午节期间，新冠疫情后旅游业和流动性的复苏似乎失去了动力，而建筑业也继续放缓，因为平均价格水泥等建筑材料跌至2017年以来新低。

;

;与此同时，财新/标普全球服务业PMI从5月的57.1回落至6月的53.9，跌至1月以来的最低值。

;

;“总的来说，两项调查都表明，在短暂的重新开放推动之后，服务业似乎正在进入新冠疫情后增长放缓的常态，”Evans-Pritchard 和 Yue 补充道。凯投宏观。

;

;

;

;PMI始终是中国经济实力的先行指标，而6月份的PMI显示经济动能依然疲软。

;

;“最近的数据显示，全球经济正在放缓，这可能会给未来几个月的外部需求带来进一步的压力，”品点资产管理公司总裁兼首席经济学家张志伟表示。

;

;“另一方面考虑到去年的基数较低，政府今年 5% 的[经济]增长目标相当温和。

;

;“目前尚不清楚疲软的经济数据是否会促使政府推出激进的刺激措施很快。”

;

;中国将于7月中旬发布第二季度国内生产总值数据，今年前三个月，世界第二大经济体同比增长4.5% .

;

;李强总理表示，中国第二季度经济增长将快于第一季度，但由于去年基数较低，因此增速更有可能更高。

;

; >;

;全球投资银行已经下调了第二季度环比增长预测，从平均 4% 以上下调至 1% 左右或低于 1%。

;

;“PMI 调查显示， 6月份中国的重新开放复苏势头继续减弱。制造业的下行压力持续存在，”凯投宏观的埃文斯-普里查德和岳补充道。

;

;“财政支持的减弱给建筑活动带来了压力。就连今年早些时候的一个亮点——服务业增长，现在也已低于疫情前的水平。

;

;“如果有更大的政策支持，经济在今年剩余时间内仍应取得一些进展。 ，但收益可能不大。”

;中国社交媒体巨头腾讯控股表示将关闭其成立八年的公司在线音频平台企鹅FM于9月份上线，中国估值最高的科技巨头继续整合其内容业务。

;

;企鹅FM已停止新用户注册，现有用户无法再向其账户充值，该业务部门周三在其网站上发表声明称。

;

;腾讯于2015年推出该平台，允许用户收听各种音频产品，包括音乐电台、书籍、新闻和聊天频道。该公司并未对这一决定做出具体解释，只是简单地将其称为“业务调整”。该公司在声明中表示，“与用户告别是一种遗憾。”

;

;分析师看好汽车音响增长，喜马拉雅首次实现盈利

;

;中国在线音频服务平台之间的竞争，在 2021 年出现了疯狂的新活动，当时美国的 Clubhouse 曾短暂流行，包括在中国，但几个月后就被屏蔽了。

;

;喜马拉雅同样由腾讯支持的播客平台拥有最大的市场份额，每月活跃用户 (MAU) 超过 1 亿。根据中国研究公司 Selection Data 3 月份的一份报告，竞争对手蜻蜓 FM 和荔枝的月活跃用户数均超过 1000 万。该报告将企鹅FM列为“第三梯队”应用，月活跃用户数超过100万。

;

;过去一年，腾讯一直在整合多项业务，试图在经济形势严峻的情况下削减成本并削减无利可图的业务。逆风和收紧的监管环境。

;

;去年 8 月，这家科技集团关闭了其内容创作应用看点，两个月前，该公司关闭了视频游戏流媒体平台企鹅电竞。

;

;与其他中国大型科技公司一样，在北京于 2020 年底发起为期两年的行业整顿后，腾讯今年的财务业绩出现反弹。然而，世界第二大经济体的增长仍然低迷。

;

;腾讯第一季度收入同比增长 11%，利润增长 10%，主要由广告和视频游戏销售推动。

;

;尽管如此，由于预计经济放缓以及可能即将到来的经济放缓受经济衰退影响，全球大型科技公司在 2022 年底和今年裁员数万人。许多中国科技公司都参与了这一趋势。

;

;腾讯在香港的股价周三收盘下跌 1.1%。

;尽管中国国家主席习近平提出倡议，但印度拒绝支持他的签名腰带和在印度主持的峰会上提出“道路倡议”，这是专家们所期待的。

;

;在周二举行的上海合作组织（SCO）虚拟峰会上，习近平表示，该基础设施项目将促进区域合作、贸易和投资，他呼吁加强“一带一路”项目的协调。

;

;刚刚完成上合组织主席国一年任期的印度和新批准的正式成员国伊朗在一份联合声明中表示不支持“一带一路”战略。

;

;“自从印度2017年成为上合组织正式成员以来，声明就一直如此。印度不太同意在联合声明中认可中国的[一带一路倡议]，并且它有自己的基础设施开发项目版本。兰州大学政治与国际关系学院教授朱永标表示，中国原本预计不会得到印度的支持。

;

;“相反，该声明表明上合组织致力于求同存异” ，”他说。

;

;新加坡南洋理工大学国际政治暴力和恐怖主义研究中心高级研究员拉斐尔·潘图奇表示，印度有实际原因拒绝支持。

;

;“一带一路经过克什米尔与巴基斯坦有争议的领土……印度人试图通过一带一路倡议与上合组织接触总是面临着一种实际的困境。他们一向非常沉默寡言。他们总是说这是一个坏主意。”潘图奇说。

;

;印度总理纳伦德拉·莫迪在峰会演讲中强调了合作打击地区恐怖主义的必要性，凸显了与北京和莫斯科的分歧。

;

;中国强调推动伊朗与巴基斯坦接触的共同威胁

;

;“恐怖主义已成为对地区和全球和平的威胁……我们必须共同打击任何形式的恐怖主义以及任何表现，”莫迪说。

;

;其他人提出了更具体的呼吁。哈萨克斯坦总统托卡耶夫敦促加强能源合作，并表示上合组织成员国应设立投资基金。习近平再次呼吁建立上合组织开发银行

;

;俄罗斯总统普京建议建立“支付基础设施”，以促进区域经济一体化并建立“独立的金融结构”。

;

;中国和俄罗斯都呼吁在上合组织成员国之间的贸易中更广泛地使用本国货币，以推动该集团内更深层次的经济一体化。

;

;但潘图奇表示，印度还有其他选择。

;

; “我不认为他们有同样的立场。他们有很多西方国家渴望与他们接触并发展自由贸易区和自由贸易关系，”他说。

;

;“对于每个人想要做的事情并没有真正达成一致。并实现……[这成为]一个优先事项不同的问题。”

;

;当莫迪谈到国家面临的恐怖主义威胁时，他说“一些国家利用跨境恐怖主义作为其政策的工具并为恐怖分子提供庇护所”。

;

;“上合组织必须毫不犹豫地批评那些将支持跨境恐怖主义作为国家政策一部分的国家。莫迪表示：“在如此严重的问题上不应该存在双重标准。”

;

;虽然没有直接提及巴基斯坦，但上海国际问题研究院研究员李红梅表示，这是一个明显的问题。提到印度的邻国，莫迪希望上海合作组织共同向其施压。

;

;中国希望上海合作组织成为安全和经济合作的平台，但印度仍然更担心恐怖主义，自塔利班以来，恐怖主义日益恶化李说，中国接管了阿富汗。

;

;中国敦促巴基斯坦、阿富汗在 2021 年以来的首次会谈中帮助打击恐怖主义

;

;“莫迪的讲话中也提到了区域互联互通，[但]这是她说：“反恐是印度的次要关切或次要目标，而反恐是印度在上合组织中的首要目标。”她补充说，自2020年在加勒万河谷与中国军队发生致命边境冲突以来，印度经济已显示出“去中国化”的迹象。

;

;尽管边界争端造成的紧张局势持续存在，潘图奇表示，新德里仍然积极参与该地区集团，并领导了多个工作组，其中包括专注于数字经济的工作组。

;

;“但它同样非常清楚的是，从印度的角度来看，由于他们与中国的敌对关系，并且他们喜欢提出一种更加不可知论的观点，因此从印度的角度来看，他们显然不愿意陷入太深的泥潭，而上合组织就是一个很好的例子。他说。

; Wed, 05 Jul 2023 23:20:02 +0800 Monday was the hottest day ever recorded, Tuesday was even hotter as global temperatures continue to risehttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/3226689/monday-was-hottest-day-ever-recorded-tuesday-was-even-hotter-global-temperatures-continue-rise?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.05 22:20;
;;

;7 月 3 日和根据缅因大学气候再分析器项目科学家的说法，7 月 4 日天气更加炎热。

;

;连续两天，全球平均气温飙升至未知区域。在科学家们讨论了周一的酷热之后，周二的气温飙升了 0.17 摄氏度（0.31 华氏度），甚至更热，这对于全球平均温度和记录而言是一个巨大的气温跃升。

;

;同样是缅因大学的气候计算器 –基于卫星数据和计算机模拟 - 预计周三的气温将达到创纪录水平，南极洲的平均气温将比 1979-2000 年的平均气温高出 4.5 摄氏度（8.1 华氏度）。

;< 7月3日至4日，魁北克省、加拿大西北部和秘鲁的高温记录被打破。美国国家气象局气象学家扎克·泰勒表示，从俄勒冈州梅德福到佛罗里达州坦帕，美国各地的城市都在历史最高水平上徘徊。北京报告上周连续 9 天气温超过 35 摄氏度（95 华氏度）。

;

;“化石燃料的使用导致地球升温并不意外，早在 19 日就已预测到。毕竟是一个世纪，”德国波茨坦气候研究所的气候科学家斯特凡·拉姆斯托夫说。 “但这对我们人类和我们赖以生存的生态系统来说是危险的。我们需要快速阻止它。”

;

;每天但初步和非官方的高温记录是在“今年真正不真实的气象和气候统计数据”几个月之后得出的，例如在俄克拉荷马大学气象学教授 Jason Furtado 表示，北大西洋、南极洲海冰创历史新低以及厄尔尼诺现象迅速加强。

;

;专家怀疑，泰国鱼类大规模死亡是由气候变化造成的

;

;这一全球记录并不完全是国家海洋和大气协会等黄金标准气候测量实体经常使用的类型。但这表明气候变化正在进入未知领域。美国国家海洋和大气管理局 (NOAA) 下属国家环境信息中心主任德克·阿恩特 (Deke Arndt) 表示，它合法地捕获了全球范围内的供暖情况，NOAA 在进行官方记录计算时将考虑这些数据。

;

;“在对于气候评估界来说，我认为我们不会像一个月或一年那样对单日观测给予如此重视，”阿恩特说。科学家通常使用更长的测量时间——数月、数年、数十年——来追踪地球变暖。此外，这一最热日的初步记录所依据的数据只能追溯到 1979 年，即卫星记录保存的开始，而 NOAA 的数据可以追溯到 1880 年。

;

;但 Arndt 补充说，我们不会除非我们正处于由温室气体排放和“强劲”厄尔尼诺现象爆发驱动的“一个可能非常温暖的时代”，否则我们不会看到任何接近创纪录温暖的日子。厄尔尼诺现象是太平洋中部部分地区的暂时性自然变暖，它会改变全世界的天气，总体上使地球变得更热。

;

;人为造成的气候变化就像全球气温的上升自动扶梯，而厄尔尼诺现象阿恩特说，就像站在自动扶梯上跳起来一样。

;

;周二，即美国独立日，地球平均气温飙升至 17.18 摄氏度或 62.9 华氏度，根据缅因大学气候再分析仪的数据，气候科学家经常使用的常用工具来了解世界状况。周二的气温比 1979-2000 年的平均气温高出近一摄氏度（1.8 华氏度），而 1979-2000 年的平均气温本身也比 20 世纪和 19 世纪的平均气温高。

;

;7 月 3 日，重新分析仪获得了该温度温度为 17.01 摄氏度（62.6 华氏度）。

;

;重新分析器基于 NOAA 计算机模拟，旨在使用卫星数据进行预测。它不是基于报告的地面观察结果。因此，这份非官方记录实际上是使用了一种专为预测而不是保存记录而设计的天气工具。

;

;7 月 3 日的全球日平均气温为 17.01 摄氏度或 62.6 华氏度。这个平均气温可能看起来不那么热，但这是该数据集 44 年来首次气温突破 17 摄氏度大关，然后甚至更高。

;

;“像这样的记录斯坦福大学气候科学家克里斯·菲尔德（Chris Field）没有参与计算，他说：“这是现在得到广泛支持的命题的又一个证据，即全球变暖正在将我们推向更热的未来。”

;

;全球平均温度更热气温对世界各地的人们来说都是残酷的条件。

;

;在美国，高温警告本周对俄勒冈州西部部分地区、加利福尼亚州北部内陆地区、中部地区等超过 3000 万人生效。据国家气象局天气预报中心称，新墨西哥州、德克萨斯州、佛罗里达州和卡罗来纳州沿海地区。他们说，亚利桑那州南部和加利福尼亚州持续发出高温警告。

;

;当高温达到峰值时，人类的健康会受到影响。

;

;“当我们变得比平时更热时，就会出现更高的气温。状况？人们不习惯这样。他们的身体不习惯这种情况，”亚利桑那州气候学家、极端天气和气候事件专家 Erinanne Saffell 说。

;

;Saffell 补充说，对于年轻人和老年人来说，这种风险已经很高，他们即使在正常条件下，他们也容易受到高温的影响。

;

;“重要的是要了解谁可能处于危险之中，确保人们补充水分、保持凉爽、不会在户外劳累并做好防护你周围那些也可能面临风险的人，”她说。

;Hongkongers' could lose their appetite for Japanese food if the country discharged treated waste water from the Fukushima plant into the ocean, some of the city's catering sector leaders have said, as lawmakers ramped up calls for a hardliner approach.

;

;Japanese media outlets on Wednesday reported the scheme could go ahead as early as August, a day after the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) said the plan “would have a negligible radiological impact on people and the environment”.

;

;The treated water from the plant, damaged by an earthquake and tsunami in 2011, will be diluted with seawater and released through an underwater tunnel. It is expected to take up to 30 years to dispose of the 1.37 million tons of contaminated water.

;

;The city's Japanese consulate has defended the scheme, saying the waster water had been treated using an “Advanced Liquid Processing System” and stressed it would not harm agricultural, marine or other food products.

;

;Over 70 per cent of Fukushima waste water fails limits: Chinese watchdog

;

;But Eric Chan, executive chef at omakase restaurant Tempura Taki, said demand for Japanese food at restaurants could drop by as much as 50 per cent once the initiative got under way.

;

;“It's going to be worse than Covid,” he said. “It's because of the general sentiments that surround the issue and not all diners will find out where exactly restaurants import their ingredients.”

;

;His restaurant brought in 90 per cent of its ingredients from Kyushu, a region in the south of Japan almost 1,500km (932 miles) from Fukushima, he added.

;

;Chan said he had not considered importing products from Fukushima prefecture even if the produce was certified safe, citing concerns from his patrons.

;

;Chan Hoi-yan, who chairs the Legislative Council's food safety and environmental hygiene panel, on Wednesday called for tough measures such as food imports from Fukushima and surrounding areas before Japan went ahead with the plan.

;

;“The radioactive water will have a wide-ranging and irreversible impact on the food chain … Japan's selfish move will make Hong Kong spend a fortune to ensure food security,” she told a radio programme.

;

;Ko Chun-kit, executive director of Japanese food importer Nic Sang Holdings Group, raised concerns about suppliers' future in Hong Kong if the country pressed ahead with pumping the waste water into the sea.

;

;“If the worst does happen, meaning that the release of water is affecting the whole ecology, this is going to affect the entire world, not just our industry,” he said.

;

;“But if imports are really affected, the livelihoods and survival of thousands of restaurants, tens of thousands of employees in Hong Kong will be on the line, and the government will have to deal with this delicately.”

;

;Hong Kong still wary of Japan radioactive water discharge plan, despite UN go-ahead

;

;Ko said Nic Sang Holdings had stopped importing food from Fukushima and the surrounding area since 2011, with most of its goods sold in Hong Kong coming from Tokyo, Osaka, Hokkaido and Kyushu.

;

;Entrepreneur Ruby Wan, who has lived in Japan for five years, said she focused on food safety checks rather than its origin when sourcing produce to sell, arguing Hong Kong and Japanese inspections were to a high standard.

;

;“General consumers might not have an idea of where different Japanese prefectures are,” she said.

;

;Wan added that she was aware the Hong Kong government had begun stricter inspections of goods from the country over the past few months.

;

;Meanwhile, Ko said his company had first-hand experience of what it was currently like to fly fresh produce into Hong Kong almost every day.

;

;“The checks are tighter now. We've always had checks, but in the past, we've never had to wait for results before departing,” he said.

;

;If a product was randomly selected for radioactivity tests, importers often needed to wait hours to get test results back, taking up “a lot of time” for fresh food, Ko added.

;

;Hong Kong's Environment and Ecology Bureau earlier said a task force was reviewing the IAEA's final report. The body would also conduct further risk assessments and seek more information from Japan about the waste water disposal plan.

;

;It also vowed that any control measures for importing such goods would be based on “scientific and risk-based principles”, as well as considering factors such as the report and the opinions of mainland Chinese experts.

;

;Hong Kong team unveils cheap 'artificial mussels' to check for nuclear pollution

;

;Appearing on the same radio show as his fellow lawmaker, Luk Chung-hung accused Japan of acting irresponsibly and urged the Hong Kong government to ban more products coming from the areas affected by the 2011 disaster.

;

;“The scope of the food ban should be wider. On top of that, Hong Kong should also consider countermeasures, be it on the economy or other aspects, to ask Japan to pay for the price of the water release,” he said.

; Wed, 05 Jul 2023 22:50:02 +0800 Taiwanese presidential hopeful William Lai stresses cross-strait status quo in bid to appease US, Beijinghttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3226674/taiwanese-presidential-hopeful-william-lai-stresses-cross-strait-status-quo-bid-appease-us-beijing?utm_source=rss_feed

;Taiwanese presidential hopeful and vice-president William Lai Ching-te has stressed to international media that he has no plans to declare independence for Taiwan if elected the island's next leader in January.

;

;Analysts said the move was aimed at reassuring the United States that he would not cause trouble, while at the same time telling Beijing he would adhere to the status quo.

;

;In an opinion piece published by the Wall Street Journal on Tuesday, Lai touted pragmatism and consistency as his top priorities if elected president of the island.

;

;Lai, 63, was nominated in April by Taiwan's ruling party, the independence-leaning Democratic Progressive Party, to run for the island's top post.

;

;“I will support the cross-strait status quo – which is in the best interests of both the Republic of China, as Taiwan is formally known, and the international community,” he wrote.

;

;“I will never rule out the possibility of dialogue without preconditions, based on the principles of reciprocity and dignity,” he added.

;

;How William Lai's 'deep green' Taiwan politics became a red line for Beijing

;

;In the opinion piece, titled “My Plan to Preserve Peace in the Taiwan Strait”, Lai also offered to implement a “four-pillar plan for peace” to address the challenges the island faces and ensure continued stability in the region.

;

;The plan includes building up Taiwan's deterrence in the face of growing military threats from Beijing, ensuring the island remains a hi-tech powerhouse and a secure link in the supply chain, forming partnerships with democracies around the world and promoting steady and principled cross-strait leadership.

;

;Despite political and economic challenges from Beijing, Lai said he would commit to working towards peace and stability “for the people of Taiwan and the international community”.

;

;A former dentist, Lai's political experience was forged in the southern DPP stronghold of Tainan, where sentiment leans towards independence. He has long been regarded as “deep green” – a reference to the more radical, pro-independence wing of the party.

;

;When he was appointed the island's premier in 2017, Lai described himself as “a pragmatic worker for Taiwan independence”, raising concerns in the US and the international community that he might declare independence if elected leader.

;

;Taiwanese analysts said that by publishing the article on July 4 – American Independence Day – Lai aimed to tell the US there would be nothing to worry about if he won the top post.

;

;“Lai knows clearly that previously identifying himself as 'a pragmatic worker for Taiwan independence' could bring uncertainties to his race,” said Li Da-jung, a professor of international relations and strategic studies at Tamkang University in New Taipei.

;

;Li said Lai must repeatedly clarify his stance to assure the US he would adhere to the policies of outgoing Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen and maintain the cross-strait status quo.

;

;The US, like most countries, does not officially recognise Taiwan as an independent state, but it opposes any unilateral change to the status quo by force.

;

;Washington warned independence-leaning Chen Shui-bian not to cause trouble when he was elected president in 2000 and repeated the same message to Tsai when she challenged Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang, then the ruling party, in the island's 2012 presidential race.

;

;Beijing regards Taiwan as its territory and has not renounced the use of force to bring it under its control.

;

;Li said although Washington, which views Beijing as its rival, does not want Taiwan to be taken under mainland China's control, it also does not want to see the island provoke a cross-strait war.

;

;Li said this explained why Lai published the article in the Wall Street Journal to try to allay US fears over his stance on independence.

;

;'Super shock waves': Taiwan People's Party may shake up politics, poll shows

;

;“He also wanted to send the same message to the international community and Taiwan's like-minded partners to assure them there would be no changes if elected,” Li said, adding Lai also hoped to use that message to win support from neutral voters in Taiwan.

;

;“It remains to be seen if such a message would convince the US and voters here that he would not bring Taiwan to a dangerous state,” Li said.

;

;Wang Kung-yi, head of the Taiwan International Strategic Study Society, a Taipei think tank, said Lai's message was also directed at Beijing, which had repeatedly warned that pro-independence forces would fail.

;

;“Beijing has long seen Lai as a deep-green figure and it is unlikely it would pay heed to what he touted,” Wang said, adding Lai must modify his stance on independence to win trust from both Beijing and Washington.

;

;“After all, the US is seeking to alleviate its rivalry with Beijing, and it would not want the next leader of Taiwan to adopt a confrontational policy towards the mainland,” Wang said.

;China is set to become the manufacturing hub for the Apple headset, and hopes were high that production of the US tech giant's first major new product in a decade would open up a new source of revenue for Chinese manufacturers. Global demand for hit products such as Apple's iPhone helped spur the emergence of assemblers such as Taiwanese company Foxconn Technology Group, formally known as Hon Hai Precision Industry.

;

;Apple CEO Tim Cook said the Apple Vision Pro, which allows users to experience digital content such as games and 3D videos overlaid onto any physical space, marked “the beginning of a new era for computing”.

;

;Analysts, however, have been cautious about short-term market reaction to the new headset.

;

;Apple has failed to “demonstrate the need to use the Vision Pro in everyday life”, and it remains to be seen “whether Apple can provide more attractive apps, content and an ecosystem before launch”, said Kuo Ming-chi, a TF International Securities analyst known for his accurate assessment of Apple's business, shortly after launch.

;

;Dan Ives, managing director of Wedbush Securities, expects initial shipments to be roughly 150,000 units for the first year, and 1 million units in the second year at lower price points.

;

;The Financial Times report said Apple was only asking for parts for 130,000 to 150,000 units in the first year from two of its Chinese component suppliers, while plans for a cheaper version have been pushed back.

; Wed, 05 Jul 2023 22:20:01 +0800 Okinawa governor Denny Tamaki traces historic Chinese links with visit to Beijing cemeteryhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3226690/okinawa-governor-denny-tamaki-traces-historic-chinese-links-visit-beijing-cemetery?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.05 22:11;

;Okinawa's governor Denny Tamaki visited a cemetery in Beijing on Tuesday to pay his respects to people from the Ryukyu Islands, who were buried there hundreds of years ago.

;

;The cemetery in the city's Tongzhou district includes several graves of people from the historical Kingdom of Ryukyu, which included Okinawa island.

;

;Tamaki will also visit Fujian, a coastal province with strong historic links to the Ryukyu island chain, during his trip to China.

;

;He is visiting with a delegation from the Japanese Association for the Promotion of International Trade, which is headed by former Japanese foreign minister Yohei Kono.

;

;On Wednesday, the delegation met Chinese Premier Li Qiang, who told the visitors that China looks forward to strengthening economic and cultural exchanges and cooperation with Japan, according to state broadcaster CCTV. He added that the two countries should be partners rather than threatening each other.

;

;In an interview with the Chinese tabloid Global Times before his visit, Tamaki said: “The long-standing history of friendly exchanges between Okinawa and China dates back over 600 years.

;

;China stokes tensions, opposition to US bases in Japan's Okinawa

;

;“In 1997, the Okinawa prefecture established a friendly relationship with Fujian province, taking friendly relations to a new level.”

;

;Trade and exchanges between Ryukyu and China flourished from the 14th century onward, and the kingdom became a tributary state to the Ming dynasty.

;

;Ryukyuans, including officials and students, were sent to study in the Chinese capital and the kingdom adopted a similar governmental system.

;

;But Japanese influence grew in subsequent centuries before Ryukyu was annexed by Japan in 1879 and became the Okinawa prefecture.

;

;Last month Chinese President Xi Jinping raised eyebrows by discussing the kingdom's links to Fujian, where he used to be governor and party chief.

;

;“When I was working in Fuzhou [the capital of Fujian], I was aware of the Ryukyu-kan [diplomats' house] and the Ryukyu cemetery there, and that Fujian had a deep connection with Ryukyu,” Xi said during a visit to a national history archive in early June.

;

;Although Tamaki welcomed the comments as evidence of Xi's willingness to develop ties with the Ryukyu Islands, some Japanese media outlets expressed concern, saying it indicated China might play up the Okinawa issue in future.

;

;Some Chinese academics have suggested that China should support autonomy for the islands, or even separatist movements.

;

;Okinawa is just 110km (68 miles) from Taiwan and has a heavy US military presence, which means that it would be a potential battleground in the event of conflict between China and the US.

;

;The Okinawa prefecture also governs the Japanese-controlled Diaoyu Islands – also known as the Senkakus – which are the cause of a long-standing territorial dispute between Beijing and Tokyo.

;

;Tamaki has been a long-standing critic of the US military presence on Okinawa and has pushed for a reduction in troop numbers.

;

;In the Global Times interview, he said the rights of Okinawa's residents had been violated by a “military-first” approach.

;

;He also alluded to the bloody Second World War battle between US and Japanese troops on Okinawa in which around a quarter of the civilian population died, saying that “all Okinawans have a heartfelt expectation that 'Okinawa must never again become a battlefield'.”

;

;Tamaki also stressed that a war over Taiwan must be avoided at all costs.

;

;Chinese woman urged to 'buy' Diaoyus after snapping up Japan island

;

;“The governments of Japan and the US should make efforts to ease tensions, establish trust through peaceful diplomacy and dialogue, and take necessary measures to prevent any unforeseen incidents,” he told the newspaper.

;

;“[Tamaki] advocates friendly relations with China and has a strong local Okinawan identity, which is the reason why we pay attention to him,” Lian Degui, a researcher from Shanghai Institute for International Studies, said.

;

;But he said the island's government was not able to do much about the US military presence.

;

;“Because the US and Japanese governments have obligations under the Security Treaty between the United States and Japan, there is no way [Okinawa] can fundamentally change the fact of US-Japan military cooperation,” he said.

;
